reviewBody: Not Verified |   On 18 July I traveled to Hartsfield-jackson airport to pick up my daughter and family. I have traveled throughout the US, Europe and Asia. I was directed to the International terminal parking by one of the many rude employees there. In the end, I parked off site until my daughter arrived picking her up at exit S2. Honestly, 'the fish rots from the head down' I ask that Governor Kemp order a top down evaluation of senior management at the Atlanta airport. If the Koreans can get it so right so can we Americans.

author: T Mayle
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Never connect through ATL on an international flight. You have people getting off flights from 2 different ends of the airport and one side has to walk all the way to the other side to get in line behind hundreds of people. Once you make it through customs and show your passport, then you pick up your checked bags and redeposit them around the corner. At this point you think you are done and can head to your gate, but no. Now you have to wait in another long line to go through security again. This is after you have been on a long international flight. Like seriously, what could I have picked up from the jet bridge to standing in the customs line? You finally make it through security and then you have to catch the train to your terminal! I have never seen such foolishness! None of this makes sense at all! If I cleared security once, why should I have to do it again?  There has to be some logic, but I don't understand it!

author: M Greg
reviewBody: Not Verified | This was my absolute worst experience I’ve ever had in an airport. It was not just the TSA although yes, they were their typical bossy, irritating organization. But the staff trying to guide us from an international arrival through passport, control, and baggage retrieval and whatever else were some of the most rude people I’ve ever encountered. I was so upset that this was going to be some of the people on my flights first experience in the United States, and they’re being yelled at and laughed at. If you fly, you know that an unfamiliar airport can be confusing. People would ask questions. Sometimes two people would ask the same question. One person I gave my passport to just flick his wrist slightly and looked at me like this. Is your passport take it the security wanted to see inside my bag and set it aside. It sat completely unattended for 10 minutes. I didn’t want to say anything to anybody because by this point, my experience had been so lousy, I figured they would purposely extend it and I might miss my connection. Restaurants are overcrowded lines of 100 people long at a Wendy’s. Bathrooms you can’t navigate because they’re too tight and people are toting bags all over the place. Flights that get delayed are not uncommon, but they seem to be more than common at this airport. I will purposely pay extra to never have to fly through this airport again. If I never see Atlanta, I will be happy. Who has a hub there, needs to act or they are going to lose customers. Because I have zero interest of flying through their hub ever again.

author: Adam Cardenas
reviewBody: Not Verified |   This airport is to be avoided if at all possible. Like many large airports, it is very busy; unlike many other airports, though, the vast majority of staff have no interest in helping anyone. Parking is full - staff waves you away without any information about alternative lots. Baggage check lines are long, staff sits on their butts, occasionally helping a customer every 5 minutes or so. Security officers are so busy yelling instructions to everyone that they can't answer a question, then lose their marbles if you do something wrong (I took my laptop out of my case like the majority of other security lines; the women started screaming like I was a child). Most restaurants inside the airport have employees staring at their cell phones, and both the service time and food quality reflect this. The only positive I can write is that this airport does allow direct flights to many places. However, I have begun to look at other airports (e.g., Columbia, SC and Charlotte, NC) to use - the extra hour or two drive is worthwhile to avoid ATL.

author: B Lewis
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Atlanta wants to be an international city but the international terminal at Heathrow provides the least convenient airport experience I have ever encountered. On arrival in Atlanta, if you want to take public transport — the MARTA subway train — you have to get a bus from the international terminal back to the domestic terminal where the train station is located. The busses run infrequently, are hard to identify, crowded, and are manned by surly drivers, They drive you around the whole large airport so it takes around 45 minutes. We’d already waited that long for a bus just to come AND spent an hour getting through a long passport control queue. Why London airports can have e-gates you breeze through in minutes and Atlanta cannot is beyond me. If you think you’ll avoid all this hassle by renting a car, think again as to access the rental car centre you have to take the same slow airport bus to domestic PLUS then a shuttle out to the rental hub. All of it adds up to it taking a very long time to just get away from the airport after an already long international flight. Signage after baggage pick-up is also very poor which makes me feel very sorry for non-English speakers or really anyone arriving in Atlanta for the first time.

author: J Mayes
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  My husband and I flew into Atlanta from Amsterdam on April 25, 2024. We had a connecting flight to Birmingham, AL following that flight that we needed to make. When we reached the Custom's line we realized that the line was extremely long and slow moving. We had enough of a layover where there should have been plenty of time to make it to where we needed to be, but there were only a few custom's officers working the arrival of an entire international flight. We asked for help from multiple employees so that we could make our connecting flight and were told that they could not help us. We were told that we would just have to miss our flight and reschedule it for the next day! This was extremely frustrating because we had recently had a similar experience in Amsterdam where the staff there had bent over backwards and had done everything in their power to help us make our flight.... so we knew that things could be done better. They have a system worked out to assist passengers with occurrences like these. Atlanta employees need to take a training class from the Amsterdam airport. I would have expected so much more from such a large airport (in the United States no less), for which I guess I just had higher expectations. We were able to make our connecting flight but only because we had to make a desperate run through an extremely large airport which left us feeling miserable, exhausted, and stressed. All in all, it was just a very bad experience that didn't have to happen. Do better Atlanta!!

author: Ken Jones
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  We had a horrible experience because they did not supply the wheelchair assistance that we requested. Our trip was from Salt Lake City to Atlanta then to Liberia, Costa Rico. Our trip home, we made a point of asking for wheelchair assistance. On our trip home, our flight was delayed an hour, so we had less time to go through customs. The wheelchair assistance was not there when we exited the terminal. There was a stray wheelchair so my wife pushed me. We kept on asking airport personnel for help and they kept on saying it is not my job. Some people offered to get someone, but that never panned out. When we picked up our bags because it was an international flight, we had three bags on the wheelchair with Ken (the person in the wheelchair) holding a wheeled 40 lb bag with a duffle bag attached to it while his wife tried to navigate to customs. At one point, a TSA official asked to take our bags, which we accepted. However we thought they would stay with us but they disappeared. We finally found the wheelchair assistance people and they did get us assistance, but was irritated that we were upset. They told us that our bags would be at our final destination and to quit worrying. They eventually took us to our terminal, although the person whined about how far it was. When we got there, the doors were closed but Delta allowed us to board. In Salt Lake, the wheelchair assistance was there and cheerfully helped us get to the luggage claim. However, I got a text from Delta stating that our luggage was still in Atlanta.

author: R Turner
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  I’ve lived outside of the US for many years and have experienced many airports all over the world. Some were good and others, not as good. Common elements I’ve found in good airports is professionalism and positive interaction with customers. My experience with the Atlanta airport contained neither of these elements. The primary area of dysfunction is the TSA process. General interaction that staff has with customers is unprofessional. No instructions given to people when approaching the document scanner, then being rude when someone is confused about the process. I did not observe any positive interaction between security staff and customers. After getting this sense, I looked for positivity and saw no eye contact or smiles, but rather what appeared to be contempt for customers. I realize that airport security would be a difficult job, and that you would feel like you are dealing with the same issue over and over. However, I have been through countless airports where security was professional and positive. Everyone has to go through security, so a good experience is crucial to a positive view of the airport. Atlanta airport has many great features, but I would not recommend it to anyone based on the TSA experience. That is how negatively it impressed me. This area should be addressed to improve service to customers and make the airport what it is capable of being.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  I fly often, domestic and occasionally international. ATL airport is poorly run as compared to other airports. It is always understaffed and very chaotic. Those of us who could walk a little, we decided to attempt to walk to the plane train, by holding the wheelchair and walk behind it. The TSA line for wheelchair people is ridiculous. No one is there to supervise the bottleneck of abandoned wheelchairs as we wobble pass the checkpoint. Do not blame the attendants! Its not their fault! Its the fault of the upper managers because they are not doing a good job of managing! It's shameful! The last trip I took there was a manager at the TSA line who was drunk and stepping on people and bumping into us and he was loud and laughing and clowning around with workers. author: E Kerr
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | 1. After completing terminal F, for international travel, many years ago. Most international flights still depart from the E and T gates. 2. While the number of gates at F are limited, there is not adequate accommodation made for arriving passengers. Instead, if arriving into an E gate and it may be on either end of the concourse, they must walk about two miles, with limited moving walkways to F gate international passport control. After all of the years that have past since completion of terminal F one would expect a solution by now. 3. Being assigned for international travel at the E gates also means you suffer the absolute chaos of dining in the central part of this concourse where, for example, there is only one coffee shop, for all of terminal E. 4. Upon exiting passport control that can be hit or miss as to ordered chaos or mayhem, one has to wait upon luggage where despite at least 6 carousels, only two may be in use, each covering several flights. This does not make any sense to me. 5. If you had done the right airport recommended parking for the international Park & Ride (the receipt says Park ATL), standby for more chaos as you exit the concourse. There are several park and ride signs on different pillars along the first pavement. However unmarked is a pillar with queuing column tape that is for white (seemingly) unmarked minibuses. These are the transport to the park and ride (that by the way should say Park ATL, same as the receipt that I paid against). 6. I can only guess that those who design, upgrade or manage ATL do not travel, themselves. International arriving passengers that arrive there are often tired, disorientated and brain fogged. Even those who have travelled through ATL extensively and live in GA, are not immune to the chaos. 7. I would not say the on site staff and ATL are rude, but they are certainly not too friendly. Returning to the US feels like the first day you report for duty in the military or I guess, arrival to start a prison sentence. This is not the America I want to project and I am sure you don't either. 8. Sadly, there is no excuse for the atrocious state of ATL and it seems that someone needs to find another career. I have little desire to fly in or out of ATL, and I do not like the airline connections from my nearest airport, here in North GA. So, if anyone from Delta is reading this, yes, it affects you too, because my wife and I will be thinking twice before we undertake the nightmare of traveling through ATL again.

author: Christian Mericle
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Their oft-repeating recorded message about this airport being the busiest and most efficient in the world is only half true. Busiest? Yes. Most-efficient? No. On its own, this isn't a very nice airport. When compared to airports like Reagan National, it's downright pathetic. The workers at the vendors were okay but the TSA staff were horrible. The facilities are adequate at best. They do have some nice art but they placed it outside the secured area (i.e., if you visit it, you'll be forced to go back through the slow security lines and deal with the rude TSA agents). Plus, the art is in a very high-traffic area on the way to/from baggage claims so stopping to look at anything is going to put you in the way of people who are already unhappy because they're being subjected to the Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. If you're stuck there overnight as I was, good luck finding food. Most of the vendors close. I was able to get food at the Burger King away from the terminals. Did I get a tasty Whopper? Nope. Burger King was out of burgers so I had to settle for something else. It wasn't very good. At least I was serenaded nearly the entire time I ate with a recorded message—Yes, they love recorded messages!—telling me that an emergency had been reported in the building and I was to stand by for further instruction (that never came).

author: J Keale
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  The busiest airport in the world could sure stand to get its act together. To its credit, the signage to access the terminals from the highways and to leave the airport were, in my opinion, ample. The majority of personnel we met in that airport, even security, were polite and professional - the only reason I'm not giving this airport a completely flunking score. That includes personnel for both Delta and Frontier Airlines. The tram connecting the terminals is clean and wonderfully efficient. Some of the Delta SkyMiles lounges are national-class, even world-class. That's where my compliments end. Now here's the bad stuff: The airport is predominantly dirty (not as dirty as Denver or Seattle, but still pretty bad). There are few places to grab a bite to eat or something to drink pre-security. The baggage and ticket counters are cramped and narrow, unbecoming of the world's busiest airport. Most departure gates are also cramped and narrow, with little seating, also unbecoming of the world's busiest airport. The security lines are astonishingly inefficient, even by US large airport standards; using CLEAR and Pre-Check in tandem should take five minutes, even on a busy holiday or weekend - not 25+ minutes like it did. If you don't have an expedited security clearance like CLEAR or Pre-Check and have to wait in the normal line, 90+ minutes to get through security on the busiest of days isn't unheard of. Again, to security's credit, the TSA officers I met were nice enough, but there clearly aren't enough TSA officers staffed at ATL. And, to the credit of the thousands and thousands of passengers being herded like cattle, people behaved relatively orderly and politely. But thousands and thousands of passengers hourly shouldn't be beholden to the whims of government incompetence - which, like I've said, is unbecoming of the world's busiest airport.

So beware of the long walk if you arrive past their normal train running schedule!!

reviewBody: Not Verified |  On August 20, I arrived from CDG to Atlanta on Delta 8606 Terminal 1 at 5.05 having a correspondence on Delta flight 1249 at 7.55pm to Tampa. The walk from Terminal 1 at one end of the airport to Gate A02 at the other en of the airport was for me a nightmare. No cart to be found, a 20 minute walk with luggage, no other form of transportation, barely a few escalators, up and down, up again and down again to get to a train, from the train another walk. I am 75 years of age and very fit yet I was thoroughly exhausted. I had already been through 2 customs when I arrived at the one in Atlanta to board my final flight, I had with me a few purchases bought at the Duty free airport in Paris. I had a mid size bottle of liquor which the custom agent insisted had to be put in my suitcase and my suitcase checked since apparently the duty free had forgotten to wrap it in a special plastic wrapper. Even though I had a receipt form the Duty free and a gift bag, the agent in no way educated enough to comprehend the difference, sent me back to the delta counter to open my suitcase, pack the bottle and register the suitcase. Thankfully I was lucky enough to find a gentleman at the Delta check-in who assisted me and was very kind. Admittedly from a few comments heard, I was not the first victim of the lack of understanding by the customs agents. One might say they are applying the rules, however is it applying the rules or is it enforcing the little power they have to unnecessarily harass travelers -  it is my understanding that they are continually inept at their job and take extreme pleasure in adding unpleasant and totally unnecessary steps to an already tired passenger? So between this and the lack of assistance for passengers to get from one point to the other in an immense airport, I will avoid that airport at all costs.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  Words almost fail me. I was transiting Atlanta on my way back to the UK from Jamaica. I was then sent back to the Virgin check in desk since Delta could not process this action. Suffice to say the Virgin check in desk was not yet open. So two hours of my life wasted because the TSA X-ray machine cannot distinguish between high quality booze and something more dangerous. I still cannot decide whether this is just vindictiveness or utterly useless technology/staff. Avoid at all cost, the place is hopeless and the staff are rude beyond description.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | My husband who is a regular customer of Delta and always flies the route SJO-ATL-SYR bought this expensive comfort class ticket hoping we will have a good experience. As a globetrotter I had never heard of such thing especially when Atlanta boasts the busiest airport and most efficient one in the world! Preposterous! My husband had requested a wheelchair on arrival and assistance. To our dismay there were no attendants at the gate. We waited until all passengers had left the sleeve and I ended up pushing the w/c through customs. We both have respiratory conditions and he has knee surgeries. The next flight to SYR was delayed, We boarded eventually and after another hour of sitting in the plane ready for take off, the pilot announced that due to storm and the crews expired time, passengers have to leave aircraft and go back to concourse A, which involves distance and riding the train. The line at the customer service was so long that it took 5 hours or 1am till 5am to finally be rebooked. Disaster airport and only three ticket agents working! As a former travel agent and world traveler, would recommend more employees and better customer service.

author: C Myers
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Aggressive, rude TSAs. My sister has sleep apnoea, to breathe at night, she must carry a CPAP machine. She has asthma, she needs a special inhaler. Her bag was pulled aside not once, nor twice, her bag was detained 'three times'. The TSA agents opened her bag, removed the CPAP machine, and failed to recognize the secondary inhaler machine as another appliance that needed to be scanned separately. Unprofessional and a waste of time. My sister was glared at, accused of being difficult, and treated with such distain and rudeness that her anxiety (for which she is on medication) spiked. Badly. It has been several hours since then, and she is still near tears when she describes her experience. An agent held his hand up in her face to cut her off when she tried to speak to him, and was spoken to both sharply and aggressively when she tried to cooperate. On top of all that, when her bags were thrown in bins to be rescanned, her brand-new neck pillow was jostled loose. Additionally, there was a forgotten black-and-red laptop that sat where it was for over 10 minutes. My sister's medical equipment got scanned three times, but nobody noticed an abandoned device for almost a quarter of an hour? Is this negligence or ignorance? The experience was disgraceful. Unprofessional is too kind a description for the treatment my sister endured.

header: "I have never had such a poor experience at an airport"
author: Danita Johnson
reviewBody: Not Verified |  The airport is very chaotic beginning with my son having to let me out in the middle of the street due to no traffic directing for departure. I have been flying Delta and a skymiles member preferring Delta due to their quality customer service until I had the most rude and disrespectful Delta agent at the luggage check in. She was very impatient barking orders for me to scan my boarding pass and not giving me time to comply before barking another order what's my name she was so impatient. I have severe arthritis and it takes me awhile to use my hands due to stiffness and lost of feeling in my fingers. I handed her my ID as the scanner did not appear to be working. She was sucking her teeth and rolling her eyes it was so uncomfortable dealing with her attitude. I ask could I check my other bag if the flight was full instead of at the gate again due to disability of having to take bags to the gate. She then saw I had my 4 lbs yorkie in her carrier and stated is that an animal. I told her yes she is a dog, I was accused of trying to sneak the dog past her. She would not allow me talk at all. I finally asked for another agent to assist me while she continued to speak to me defensively. Finally another agent come over and took care of me while she continued to fuss in front of him. I asked her please stop speaking to me you are very rude and unprofessional. She threatened to not let me on the flight. I asked why because your being rude I have never had such a poor experience at an airport. I paid the pet fee and thanked the gentleman for helping me. He was very professional. Once I went through security with my pet. The agent that tested my hands was rude and yelled at me because I set my dog down on the counter to prevent from dropping her as he asked for my other hand. Yelled at me to don't put the dog on the counter as if she had rabies. She is a 4lb yorkie. I said sorry please don't yell at me I'm trying not to drop my dog. He was very rough with swabbing my hand and dismissive. I rarely write reviews but I have to let Atlanta know you need to do better. Not coming back through anytime soon. I will also be making complaint to Delta regarding treatment of passengers with disabilities need extra time to preform request. Different airports have different requirements so more signage directions should be visible.

author: N Keare
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  My Son and I had a 4 hour layover, found our gate and parked it right there. We spent much of the 4 hours chatting with the "nice" lady behind the counter and when it came close to the time we thought we should get a seat assignment to Charleston, she stated she needed to board a flight to PA and then she would get us our seat assignments. She boarded the first flight and then left. Another agent came up and we asked him if we could get the seat assignment and he stated that the gate changed 15 minutes prior. We ran to the gate (which was about 4 up from where we were) and they closed the doors and we "missed" the flight. We then needed to find another flight but I was hot. No one was accountable just repeatedly stating that we need to watch the monitors as it was our responsibility. Yes. I 100% agree if I hadn't been in almost constant communication with the lady who stated she would be the one to help. Everyone I talked to was rude and lacked any kind of empathy or accountability. If one more person stated that "We change gates all the time, you need to watch the monitors" I thought my head would explode. Whatever happened to common courtesy, or better yet, common sense? Why would I stare at a screen if the lady behind the desk stated she was the one to check us in? We lost an entire day of work and the expense was huge. Thank goodness for that free drink voucher.

author: Victoria Lewis
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | What happened to this airport? I used to rave about this before, being one of my most favorites in the world. But I breezed through that line in less than 10 minutes. Luggage claim and rechecked no problem. After recheck, passengers were about to go through security when we were all redirected to the TSA line upstairs. This was where the mess all started. The lines were very very long, and were hardly moving. There were a few times when the lines just stopped. The smart move would have been to open more metal detectors to get the lines moving, instead the TSA officers were just standing around. They only had three conveyors/detectors opened. Why? This airport was so much better than this. Today was a major disappointment. As a result, I missed my connecting flight to Orlando. And vowed to never fly into this airport again if I could help it.

header: "The TSA were completely and unnecessarily rude to my dad"
author: K Moore
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Currently holding a temporary residence here at Robins AFB, Georgia. My father drove my car down so that I would have transport to leave base, however, we wanted to fly him back home. I flew in to Atlanta and had just a few issues with my arrival into this airport so I figured it wouldn’t be awful if I booked a flight for my father to fly out of there. I cannot begin to describe how awful the experience was for my dad and I. The TSA were completely and unnecessarily rude to my dad who is easily confused and older, acted as if he had COVID or was diseased. The TSA agent literally looked as if she was about to draw a weapon on my dad because he was six feet away from her? Additionally the representative at the Delta check-in desk who is posted there to help guests pre-check for their tickets was also so awfully rude. Asked again, another simple question and she acted as if we were burden to ask her anything instead of just letting her stand there and ruin her uneventful day. Normally at my hometown airport, they usually let my dad come into the terminal with me to say goodbye as any day I could get orders to deploy and won’t have a chance to say goodbye before I go. But at this airport, I felt as though they were snatching him away from me and I was afraid he wasn’t going to make his flight because it is an extremely large airport and he is older and just overwhelmed easily. Thankfully and barely, he made it to his gate. He then told me that he was just extremely disappointed because the associates at the counter by the terminal were rude over the intercom every time they used it and just rude to other guests that went up to the counter. It made him so uncomfortable with the entire experience that he never wants to fly out of the airport again and would love it if I never did either. It made him so upset that he ended up crying part of his flight home. He’s concerned that somethings going to happen to me on deployment and he would’ve never gotten to have said goodbye. Simple things like this go a long way for paying customers. Having this experience, I think I will follow my dads advice and fly out from Savannah or another airport the next chance I actually get to fly home.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  Arrived Atlanta from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Be prepared for a long walk from the gate to Passport Control. I would say it was fairly well organized as they had people directing passengers to the booths. Not a bad experience. Just be prepared for a long walk and a long wait/standing. Here is my major complaint about this airport if you are arriving on an international flight. If your final destination is Atlanta and you wish to catch a ride share, MARTA or a hotel van, passengers are required to ride a small shuttle bus to Ground Transportation which takes 20 minutes. We had two heavy suitcases which had to be lifted into the bus. As we are over 65, it was difficult. Getting passengers from the international terminal to ground transportation in the main terminal is very inefficient and inconvenient.

Once I got through my feet were filthy with dirt and crud all over the floor. I had 3 elderly people in our group in wheelchairs. 2 of them were helped to the gate by employees. We found our gate around 6 am. There are many restaurants in the airport but none of them open. Once a Dunkin Donuts opened the line was all the way down the corridor.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | For a large airport, this is one of the worst I’ve come across. The gates are filthy, the information is lacking, and the online resources are lacking. The one bright spot was a meal at One Flew South, a unique menu well prepared, but we barely got there before their kitchen closed at 6.30 pm. The public WiFi is pathetic. While writing this review, sitting in terminal D, I have had to reconnect a half-dozen times. And there are no visible charging stations. Another problem here is the attitude of public who are evidently, we were told, protesting having to wear masks in the airport. Can’t tell you how many people — including flight crew members — we saw walking the terminals with their masks under their noses or completely off. This may be something common in the area, but since mask wearing is a requirement of all airports — and other airports have signage about how to wear a mask — it would seem there is something Atlanta Hartsfield could make a better effort to keep their passengers safe. Clean it up, Atlanta!

author: S Wilson
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | This is probably the worst airport I have been through. And I once worked at JFK with its many terminals. I had to transit through this airport from Costa Rica to catch a domestic flight to JFK NYC. There are no restrooms in the immediate area. The plane I came off had one aisle. And the flight attendants spent a good deal of time using the aisle to serve snacks. So it's not always convenient to use the restroom on the aircraft. Common sense you would think they would place restrooms near where the gate is where we got off the plane. Then it's not like you can just walk to the CBP area. We had to stand there for as much as 15 minutes and more at least twice before being allowed to proceed to the long line to present our passports. Walking from the gate to the CBP seems like 1/4 of a mile. There were hundreds of people on the line. There is a restroom in that area but with such a long line and a connecting flight less than two hours of my arrival I did not want to chance using it then getting on line. The saving grace was that the customs officer did not take long with my passport. He basically looked at my photo, asked me to remove my mask then asked me if I am who it says I am. Then I was on my way. It took over one hour to exit the CBP line. Someone took my luggage and put it on the belt to be sent to my JFK NYC flight. As soon as we walked out of that area we all had to go through security as if we had just walked off the street. I overheard one of the TSA agents telling someone that until you reach age 75 you have to remove your shoes. Well around where I live I see people who could barely get on the bus without the driver lowering the stairs. And many of these people are not even 50 years old. After going through security I checked the board but could not find my flight listed. I asked a lady at information desk. She told me I had to take the shuttle train on the right hand side one stop to area E. And go to E11. I went to E11. No such flight. I went to the Delta counter I saw when I came to area E. The lady told me I had to go to E 31 and the flight is about to leave so I had to hurry. I was the last person to get on the plane when I heard them say they were about to close the door. A gate agent came with me. She said there was no more room for my carry-on so I had to check it but not before I removed my laptop and camera which most likely would be stolen. My advice is avoid this airport if you're connecting from an international flight. Connecting domestic to international was not an issue when I was leaving. Unless you got four hours between international arrival and your departure connection don't risk it. And putting a restroom all the way in the customs area serves no purpose because most people need to use the restroom as soon as they exit the plane. This airport is badly designed. When I was leaving for Costa Rica I arrived after 8 am on a weekday morning and none of the restaurants were open. Not even a place to serve coffee. It's as if the airport was designed for the convenience of airport staff and not its passengers!

header: "there are 8 restaurants in the food court and only 1 is open"
author: Robert Scott
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I travel through this airport a minimum of 4-times a month. On my return trips I typically arrive around 6.30 to 6.45 pm. Almost all restaurants are closed. It's the strangest thing. This is not an occasional situation. It's every evening visit. Who is managing this airport? Why is this the case? After talking to employees at the information center, I've found out the restaurants close at 4:00 +/-. Now there's a couple of the larger restaurants open like TGI Fridays open, but most people w/ connectors don't have that much time. Currently, I'm in E terminal and there are 8 restaurants in the food court and only 1 is open [McDonald's]. Now there like a 100 people in line so that's not an option. All but (2) of the he convenience stores are closed and those have huge lines. The restaurant services should be for the peoples convenience and not the restaurant's convenience. Why hasn't the management observed this and made adjustments? I don't think they should stay open all night, but this is a little ridiculous. I'm sure they will blame this on COVID, but this has been going on long before COVID (I've been traveling through here for years). My guess it has a little to do with the controlling power of the political power of the mayor and her cronies.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  This is the most unorganized airport I’ve ever been to. They had us going every which way, but the right way. Then after going through the gauntlet of passport control then I stepped in a room of mass hysteria to get my luggage, then drop it off. Then I was directed to go upstairs to check in for my connecting flight, only to be told they don’t have TSA precheck. After going through the security check then I had to go back downstairs to catch a train to go to my terminal which was filthy. The only light to this was the handsome CBP security officer who stopped to check my passport. He was the highlight of me coming back from Puerto Vallarta! This airport needs to do better. It was a complete disaster!

author: David Greene
reviewBody: Not Verified |  This airport wins the prize for the world's most expensive yet disgusting airport food and the unfriendliest food court staff. It was my first ever transit/visit via US, so I cannot compare to other US cities. However, having traveled a lot for over 20 years, it is appalling. There is hardly anything to eat, other than McDonald's at Terminal D, so I had to go to Terminal A. Well, the prices are mad, you pay 5.99+tax for a cup of coffee and 10.99+tax for a chicken salad. I asked them for any oil or sour cream or anything for my salad but they only have mayonnaise or mustard or ranch sauce. They DO NOT understand the concept of food allergies. If you have any kind of allergy or intolerance, do not go to this airport. Other notes - very crowded and noisy, you cannot get anywhere to rest quietly. I am giving it 2 rather than 1 because it's relatively clean. Avoid at any length of you can!

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Extremely limited spots to recharge electronics. So - the many outlets placed under the seats are rendered useless. C’mon Atlanta. We travelers don’t ask for much. A couple of food options, a place to sit, and a place to recharge our phones. It’s how we use our time - by doing work on our laptops, staying in touch with loved ones as we travel, and entertaining ourselves with what for many is a few moments to ourselves. We even bring our own equipment - we just need access to outlets. I think we pay a tax to travel through - right? Please fix this big oversight. (Shout out to the sections between terminals, if one chooses to walk. Beautiful and informative displays! But - hard to remember when I couldn’t charge my phone).

author: H Allen
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | We had to connect through Atlanta on a flight from London Heathrow to Orlando. We had enough time for the connection and as the plane landed slightly early there should have been no problem. When we got to Passport and Immigration control there was a huge queue and very few staff on duty. We waited well over an hour in this line before we were allowed to go through. Then to our horror we found that we had to go through security again even though we had been through security at Heathrow and had not left the airport. Going through the channel for connecting flights should have made things easier but the staff seemed to not be aware or didn’t care that people had other flights to get to. The security channel was chaos - there was no proper line, it was totally disorganised and the staff were surly and unhelpful. Lots of people were in danger of missing their flights but they just didn’t care! They seemed to take pleasure in working as slowly as they could. We had to run to our departure gate but it had been closed and even though it hadn’t left we couldn’t board. We weren’t the only people to miss that flight and we met lots of people who had also missed their connections because of this incompetence. As we couldn’t get another flight till the next day we had to pay for overnight accommodation. I would never travel through this dreadful airport again.

author: M Leeson
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | 9 of us were supposed to fly out of the Hartfield Jackson airport to go to Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic for a family vacation. We were supposed to travel by Swift Air, a small charter company. Atlanta Airport is huge and all of us were at the airport international terminal 3.5 hours before our flight. We have looked around for Swift Air signs but did not see any, so we asked 3 different airport customer service representatives, showed them our travel documents, and all of them told us that we have to go to the Domestic terminal, even though it was an international flight. We also stopped by the information desk at the international terminal, showed our paperwork, the customer service representative checked something on her computer and also advised us to go to the domestic terminal. It takes at least 20 min to get to the Domestic terminal plus the waiting time for the shuttle. Once we got there and run around through the whole terminal, asked several staff members, who had no idea where Swift Air was, we finally got to one of the TSA members who used his radio to find out that Swift is at the International terminal. After we spend $50 on the taxi for 20 min drive, since we were running out of time, we got back to where we started. We ran through the whole terminal and finally found Swift Air counters all the way in the back of the terminal with no signs in the whole airport to guide people where to go, except for the signs on top of the counter. Also, all of the international terminal staff members had no clue where Swift Air counters were! We got to the counter 45 minutes before the flight, but we were denied boarding, as well as another family of 5, who went through the same ordeal. I do not understand why airport employees are incompetent and not knowledgeable. No one knows which airline is located at what terminal. Due to all of this, we had to purchase new tickets from Birmingham, AL with a connection back in Atlanta, for the next morning. We had to rent 2 cars, drive 3 hours to AL, fly back to Atlanta to finally board to Punta Cana, all due to the incompetency of staff working at the airport. I always thought that one of the largest international airports in the US would have exceptional customer service, but I was so wrong.

TSA is a nightmare as all passengers for all airlines pass through a central checkpoint which is so incredibly slow, the slowest service I have ever encountered (including Orlando which at least spilts to two terminal wings) and I’ve been through a number of airports. Even the TSA Pre line had about a half hour plus wait. The airport itself looks old although clean and seems to lack some of the new tech like charging stations for devices that you would expect to find in this day and age. I flew JetBlue out of JFK for this trip and what a difference between JetBlues own terminal 5 and this hole in the wall. If you can avoid passing through this airport I highly recommend it as many of the people don’t really seem to care about the travelers passing through and if you have a connecting flight that’s either at a distant gate or concourse you may miss your flight as they are so far away. There are no terminal shuttle carts like you would find in other big airports like Dallas or Raleigh Durham.

author: T Davidson
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Atlanta airport is without a doubt the worst airport in the US. Also, the facility is not in the greatest shape for such a prominent airport, and I seem to encounter a lot more rude people there between security line herders and unfriendly airline staff; attitudes abound. I don’t know what’s in the water in Atlanta, but I think the ATL Airport Authority and airline management would be well served to get out of their office and walk around the terminals more and see the experience us travelers are having in their airport. While I love the city of Atlanta, I dread having to travel there for business every time due to the very negative aspects of the airport experience.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | February 18, 2019 arrived on Delta 733 from Cancún. Flight was on time. Had wheelchair requested because I can’t walk fast enough to get from point A to point B on time because of knee and hip issues. There was no chair at the plane, so I began to walk. The first person I came to was at immigration. I ask about a chair and her reply was that I should have stayed at the plane. She ask another “worker” but while they stood there telling me it was my fault, I continued on because at immigration we had to stand in line on one side of the building to be able to then let go in groups to stand in line on the other side. I ask immigration officer if he knew who I could ask about it. He said Delta desk. Ask another man on the way to baggage claim. He said down stairs. Ask a young man down stairs, he said down hall on right. Never saw a desk. Checked bag again, then ask a Delta employee, who ask another ”worker” if she had a radio. No response! Went through security and ask what gate our flight left from because it wasn’t on ticket. Had to go back upstairs to E5. When we got back upstairs saw a young man in a golf cart who ask if we needed a ride to our gate. Was so thankful for this offer, I could have cried! It wasn’t that much farther but I could hardly put one foot in front of the other. This is the first time I have ever ask for a chair and not got it but it was very inconvenient and painful. Your job to have chair at plane when it’s clearly on boarding pass. Your attention please, so it doesn’t happen again. Wouldn’t want someone more unable than I to have this problem, and receive no more help than I did.

author: Elizabeth Neger
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  The immigration and passport check for US Citizens returning to the US was appalling. We almost missed our flight with 1hr and 42 minutes between flights, all spent in one very poorly organized and understaffed immigration area. We usually fly into JFK on flights from Europe so we are very familiar with the procedure but I have never seen such a poor arrangement as the one in Atlanta. We were returning from Guadeloupe to Newark via Atlanta on a Saturday evening and joined approximately 800 others arriving from So. America and the Caribbean who were 90% returning American citizens. We were funneled into a huge room full of crazy 8 lines and zig zags of lined up people being directed by airport attendants who tried to be helpful but it was pretty hard to help with directions. And there were only about 8 of them and maybe 10 immigration officers. There would have been triple that number at JFK. The airport personnel tried to help expedite the kiosks (which don't generally help because no one really gets what you're supposed to do - the cards were easier!) in our case these people were quite helpful, but you had to wait in line for every step. It took us a full 1hr 30 min. to get through that, many of us figuring we were never going to make our next flights. An airport employee did look up our gate for us. Of course it was at the literal other end of the terminal (from Term F to A). Then we had to get our bags (6 carousels with 4 flights on each one....!) and get them to the next point where the baggage handlers were actually very efficient and pleasant despite the total chaos. They seemed used to it. Then security again which because of the throngs of people (we had already been through it anyway), they just sort of let us pass by except for a few poor souls who had to have their things inspected. They need many more immigration officers working at that airport and it would have been very embarrassing to witness that scene with foreign nationals trying to navigate it. Not a very nice "Welcome to America".

author: M Andrews
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | After returning from a trip in Central America, my family and I had to go through customs. This was not our first time having to go through customs. As we arrived at customs, the line was huge. We were sent down a hallway, where we waited in a line that zig zagged forever. Once we reached the area where we would choose which section to go (U.S. citizens, foreign visitors, mobile passport), we went into the mobile passport line. After waiting in the line for about fifteen minutes we realized we were waiting in the wrong line. That line was for foreign visitors. So we went back and asked again and she told us we were in the wrong line. We finally were in the right line after waiting already about two hours in line for customs so far. All of our flights were departing soon so we needed to get through customs and security quickly. As we approached the stand for mobile passport, the woman who was working rudely asked us if we were a family living in the same household. We replied no, and then took one family at a time. She was the most unpleasant agent I have ever encountered. She was miserable. She was not respectful at all! I understand that she deals with a lot of people during the day but that is no reason for her to be miserable and rude to people entering the country. It is so embarrassing to think about people coming to the United States for the first time. The first they encounter is horribly long lines for customs and then rude employees. At the point in customs I was so embarrassed to be an American. I have traveled through the Atlanta airport many times and every time it is more and more disappointing. Such a disappointing experience. I will now avoid traveling through the Atlanta airport. We all almost missed our flights. After customs the security was so disorganized. The employees didn’t seem to know anything or know what the heck they were supposed to be doing. Horrible experience in the Atlanta airport.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I travel through Atlanta Airport several times a year, and generally find little to complain about considering the size of it together with the vast amount of travelers that travel through it. I also realize that my complaint is not necessarily due to the airport authorities but rather to Border & Customs Control. With the recent additions of passport kiosks where the traveler enters their passport and customs declaration, I thought that would speed up the process of entering the country from abroad, but this is not the case. We still have to present our credentials to be inspected by a decreasing number of officers. This has increased the entry time drastically. As a US citizen, having to wait for 2-1/2 hours in line to be seen by an Immigration officer is beyond belief.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | For one of the busiest airports in the country, the South Terminal has the absolute least efficient checkpoint. First, there is only a single checkpoint for 8 terminals. Second, the lines for SWA Flyby and other priority board are barely marked or nonexistent. Then the security scan allows people from behind you in line to move past you and push their bags through such that there is an inevitable backlog wherein the people who have already put their belongings in bins are waiting to push those bins through and people who have already gone through body scan are waiting for their luggage, instead of making any attempt whatsoever to keep luggage with owners during the process. Only the trains run with any respectable efficiency to reduce the trek from rental car drop-off to gate to a mere mile. Nearly 2 hours from car to gate is unacceptable for such a central airport. I will avoid flying through here at all costs in the future. Also, unable to get on the wi-fi.

author: M Wilson
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Typically I don't write reviews for poor service because I believe that most people don't write them for good service either. However, the customer service at Atlanta-Hartsfield airport has been consistently very rude and condescending. It's become so common place that I don't even want to choose Delta anymore to avoid going through Atlanta. Almost every employee has an attitude and you can tell they think it's funny to be rude. I went to the food court to get a slice of pizza and am greeted with, "what u want?". When I politely said, "I'm sorry", the employee repeated herself. I proceeded to be nice and smiled throughout my experience only to be met with mumbling, no eye contact and laughter among the employees. It's not just the food service employees. I witnessed an older gentleman who was an airport employee ask another young employee for help with an elderly passenger. The young employee responded with some verbal disgust and then she proceeded to roughly handle the elderly passenger in a wheelchair. I really think the airport should focus on customer service relations and training. Every experience I've had there has involved a minimum of one, and usually more than one rude employees. Please be advised that I'm not talking about any TSA employee. They have a tough job and aren't part of this conversation. I would have airport management take off their uniform and interact with the airport employees. It won't take them long to see what myself and many others are telling them. Quite frankly, I'm extremely embarrassed the customer service at Atlanta-Hartsfield is what many foreign travelers base their opinion of Americans and our hospitality on.

author: Marvin Reader
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Airport Authority severely punishes ride-share (Uber/Lyft) users. This is truly my least favorite airport in the US. Part of it is the fact that as I fly out of the DFW airport most of the time, I am usually on American Airlines and their gates at the Atlanta airport are about a mile from any ground transportation area. I have suffered that indignity in silence for several years, however I finally was tipped over the edge this latest trip when I dared to use Uber/Lyft at the airport. The airport authority clearly has a strong distaste for ride share companies and is doing all they can to frustrate travelers from using them. After walking a mile from the gate to the ground transportation area, I had to ask 3 individuals how to get to the ride share area before I found the down escalator nestled among the baggage carousels that took me to the correct exit. Upon finding the exit, it was another mile walk outside in the Atlanta heat to the designated ride share pickup area. At that point, as the ride share app would not let me choose a location for pickup until I was there, I had to wait another 10 minutes for the Lyft driver to come from their designated wait area. The drivers for the ride shares are also confused about where to pull in to pick up passengers and there was often traffic bottlenecks as folks loaded up. There were also about 100 riders waiting in the pickup area and this was at 8.30pm on a Monday night. The ordeal added at least 30 minutes to my arrival time and left me hot and angry. Let me repeat, the Atlanta airport sucks.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I frequently travel out of Atlanta airport and the last time was in May 2018 and it was a disaster with TSA! I am very disappointed in Atlanta TSA - actually I'm still very angry at the rudeness they showed. reviewBody: ❌ Not Verified |  Our flight from Providenciales landed a bit earlier than scheduled in ATL, landing around 5:15. Our next flight to Indianapolis was scheduled to depart at 7:24 pm. Getting through Customs and security was an absolute nightmare. After clearing customs and security, we had to move quickly and arrived at our gate for the next flight as they were boarding Zone 2. We had nothing to declare, there weren't any issues with us, the problem is the lack of adequate working staff for the volume of people attempting to clear customs. Everyone around us was frantic about potentially missing their connections and there is no recourse because as were told by the airport employees "everyone here has a connecting flight". We have no intention of ever taking another international flight that requires us to go through customs in Atlanta. We have cleared customs in O'Hare, Dallas, Miami, and New York, and Atlanta is by far the most unorganized, poorly staffed and chaotic we have encountered and will be avoided in the future unless you have four to five hours between connections.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | After reading the reviews of this airport and being fully aware of its humongous size, one has to be apprehensive about using this airport. But my recent trip through Hartsfield was totally stress free. I arrived in Terminal 1 and had to connect at an end gate in Terminal 3 and I had exactly 2 hours and 1 minute to accomplish this. The directional signs were prominent and plentiful and I took the shuttle train that connects the terminals - no wait for it at all. All the terminals had plenty of eateries at all price points. I found many chairs to sit. Bathrooms were located at convenient intervals in each terminals and were clean with working faucets, liquid soaps and paper towels. Announcements at the gates were frequently made. Big display boards listed all departing flights and gates. It was a very smooth connection I had without causing any anxiety or uncertainty. It is a remarkable accomplishment to process so many people all the time every day!

author: Keely Adams
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  This has to be the worst airport I’ve had the displeasure of travelling through. The staff were rude and completely unhelpful and seemed to shift lines about randomly so some people ended up through quicker despite others having earlier flights to catch. We asked several times, as did others, what to do about our connecting flight and were quite bluntly told it was basically tough luck and the only option was to see if people would let you cut in line. If that’s your only suggestion what exactly is your job role here other than to stand around and annoy people? We then had the same queue and problems at security therefore missing our flight. The staff at the Delta desk were also very rude and blamed the fact that it’s the busiest airport in the world. Clearly better systems should be in place if that’s the case. The consequence was that we had to actually pay to stay in a hotel overnight so we could fly the next morning. An absolute shambles of an airport with rude and very unhelpful staff. I’ve used many airports around the world for transit and have never had this issue before.

reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified | Missed Flight to Milwaukee because gate change not called out. author: C Mitchell
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | In transit from Punta Cana (Dom. Rep.) to Amsterdam. The largest and busiest airport in the world, but clearly under-capacity. Bag drop and customer assistance counters had reasonably short wait times, but queues for immigration and security checks were very long, even at off-peak times. The immigration officer I had was much more polite and respectful than most of those I've experienced at US airports. TSA agents were polite and seemed professional, if a little laid-back. Some areas of the airport have better food options than others, depending on which concourse/terminal you're in. One thing that caused me some stress was the fact that I received different answers from different personnel. Every time I've passed through the US in the past, I've always had to clear immigration with my baggage (i.e. collect baggage from the carousel, clear immigration, then drop off baggage again). As my baggage wasn't on the carousel, I asked a few airport personnel, who were all polite and friendly enough, but they all told me different things. Some said always collect your baggage, some said it wasn't necessary because of my final destination, some said my luggage must have been lost, and some said to check at the gate when boarding (which would have been too late at that point). My layover was 2hrs 25mins. I only arrived at the departure gate around 20 mins before scheduled departure time, which was 40 mins after they started boarding. My advice would be to leave yourself at least 3 hours between flights but, even at that, you won't have much time to eat, shop or relax. Because of this, I will avoid this airport in future.

author: Harsh Deep Singh Narula
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | ATL is the busiest airport in the United States, so you'd assume that the ground staff and TSA folks at this airport take their jobs seriously, and are efficient. Unfortunately, that's not true. As someone who's traveled extensively through the US (every week) and internationally (several times a year), I'd like to believe I've seen the gamut of airport experiences. ATL continues to be one of the worst on my list (rivaling SEA). The security screening process at ATL is an absolute nightmare. It's the slowest, most inefficient security check process I've seen. It'll take you well over 35-40 mins to get to the TSA officer who screens your boarding pass, and that's on a "good" day. The TSA staff can clearly see the huge line, but refuse to open up more checkpoints/belts. Worse, the airport monitors continue to project a delusion that the wait time at all the checkpoints is less than 15 mins. I'm baffled how they could lie outright like that. Another issue is the belts for carry on screening. They have a bin system, wherein you have to fill up several and push them on to the belt. Leads to all sorts of confusion, and I've timed it and know for a fact that it's slower than the simple "push through" at most major airports. Overall, despite being the busiest airport in the country, ATL has a huge scope for improvement in terms of the efficiency of the security screening and boarding process.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | We flew from Cancun Mexico to Atlanta for a connecting flight to London, we passed security as expected in Mexico without any issues the process was thorough but quick, in fact the flight was able to leave a bit early which allowed us two and a half hours to catch our connecting in the same terminal. Staff in Atlanta are on a different planner, their streaming process is haywire, they don't want to help and basically kettle everyone like cattle into pointless queues and then have the nerve to have a go at customers for minor misunderstandings. Yes it was quite busy but not so much so to cause this much chaos. Also going to the desk to report missing our flight Delta were not at all interested and just wanted to move the problem onto someone else or rather blame someone else. I work in this business in the UK and am aghast at how utterly useless staff are here. Taking this all into account at the end of the day this was only a connecting flight, we were not even entering the US so completely ruined what was a nice holiday.

header: "we'll try to avoid using Atlanta in future"
author: C Simpson
reviewBody:
✅ Verified Review |  
My wife and I were flying from the UK to the US to see the Total Solar Eclipse, we officially had just over 1.5 hours to make our connection to Denver, and were told that this would be tight. We actually arrived ahead of schedule, which was great, and then we got to immigration. Used the automatic terminals, which we thought were going to be a great time saver, but then we had to queue for an immigration officer, and our line didn't move for nearly an hour - what's the point in the auto terminals when you still have to queue anyway? Managed to get to our departure gate with about 10-15 minutes to spare (the "Plane Train" shuttle breaking down 3 times didn't help). During all this time no-one told us what the delay was caused by, and the (2) officers working the immigration desks were so slow it was almost unbelievable. By the time we finally got through the line behind us was huge, and there must've been people that missed connections - we were just lucky. Wherever possible, we'll try to avoid using Atlanta in future.

reviewBody: The new international terminal is a joke. There's no overnight parking at the international terminal, the only way is to park at one of the other lots and take a shuttle. This was such a colossal mess I'd drive to Birmingham or Columbia just to take the airport there and not have to deal with Hartsfield.

reviewBody: This is the first time I have felt motivated to write a review about an airport, with the hope that some Airport officials might read it. Personally, I don't understand the purpose of having to collect one's baggage, and then re-check it. I don't believe that European airports make you do this. If this step could be eliminated, in other words if I could check my baggage in Madrid and not have to see it again until Memphis, the whole process would be a lot speedier, I understand this may not be possible with smaller airports where there is no customs and border patrol, but many airport (including Memphis) are so-called "international" airports and ought to be able to do this.

reviewBody: ✅ Verified Review |  Never have I seen such a shambolic process and never anywhere in the world have I met such surly and rude officials. What was truly astonishing was the fact that the truly miserable and obnoxious officials seemed to somehow relish the chaos they were causing. Throughout most of this time only about 4 booths were operational with most standing unoccupied. In our case, my family had 3 and a half hours between flights but we still missed our onward connection. I personally was led like a criminal to a locked room with several others in order to answer questions regarding something which "showed up" on their computer system. The Officer who spoke at me (at not to) clearly had problems understanding the system and eventually I was told that there was a glitch in the system and was free to go. Needless to say no hint of an apology. Having just retired after 30 years in the Police Force I am a staunch supporter of offialdom and of Police and Customs everywhere but I have to say I was astonished at the attitude of the Officers I met and the general shambolic system at Atlanta. One place in the world I will never ever return to.

reviewBody: ✅ Verified Review | We've just had our first transit experience at Atlanta and it will assuredly be our last - and that goes for the US as a whole, if Atlanta's inefficient, officious and frequently offensive staff are representative of national practice. Like many other correspondents, we nearly missed our connection, having only allowed 3 whole hours to get through this mess of a 'homeland security system'. Two desultory officials on the 10+ Esta / visa checking desks. Nobody in a hurry, nobody bothered as hoardes of clearly stressed and distressed passengers who'd waited for hours pleaded for help because they were risking missing their flights (many we saw today did). Representative comment from man vaguely minding the queue: 'ain't my problem'. Then downstairs to join another massive queue to go through security screening again (we'd earlier spent 4 hours checking in and being screened in Guatemala). And all the while being barked at by staff standing around chatting (plenty of those available, apparently, after the Esta staff shortage upstairs). Example of one crass command screamed at me (I had the temerity to be pulling my carry-on bag behind me in the queue): 'Bag in front of you - now!' Great welcome to 'the Land of the Free' to be treated like a criminal when you're just trying to change planes - having already submitted to - and paid for - the intrusive Esta check online. It's a shameful, stress-inducing shambles - to be avoided at all costs.

author: Gerald Webb
reviewBody: Cannot praise my experience of arriving and exiting Atlanta airport enough. The Customs and TSA agents were extremely welcoming. Although, I was not under pressure to get through the queues it was nice to be "asked" if any persons were in need of onward connections or needed to pass through quickly. Outside, the bus connection service was regular and prompt. Departing through the airport was an equally pleasant experience. From the boarding card personnel to the TSA agents (plenty of staff to offer a speedy search). It was great to walk through the departure lounges and read the history of the racial struggles. Also, great smoking facilities, with proper extraction fans. A reasonable food court with a vast selection of options, Would use Atlanta airport again in a heartbeat. Keep up the good work.

author: J Krinsky
reviewBody: This review is for Atlanta domestic. Atlanta is my hometown airport. For such a large and busy airport, I find that it operates very well. Unlike LAX or JFK where airlines operate out of several terminals, ATL has one central security checkpoint giving passengers access to all gates (concourses A to F). At LAX or JFK, passengers might need to go out on the sidewalk and walk to another terminal. For example, in Atlanta if you fly in on Delta and are connecting on American, you do not have to leave the terminal or go past another security checkpoint. Just get on the train to change concourses. There are many shops and eateries past security. If you have lots of time, your can go back and forth between the concourses to check out the shops and eateries. My only complaint is that when coming off a flight there are no signs directing passengers to baggage claim.

author: Adam Berry
reviewBody: A two week honeymoon of de-stressing and relaxing ruined by the the most stressful airport experience I've ever had. Flying from Cancun to Atlanta, for a connection to London Heathrow, we were told on check-in in Cancan and multiple times on the Aircraft and on arrival in Atlanta that regardless of our destination we would have to claim our luggage from the baggage carousel and re-check it for the connection flight. Our flight from Cancun arrived at 6.30pm, with our connection flight boarding at 7.35pm, so already tight on time. When we got through customs we were pointed by an airport employee to the carousel from which we could collect our luggage. Super. What followed was a twenty minute wait before the carousel even began to move, time was slowly ticking away. A further 10-15 minutes was spent watching most others from our flight collect their bags and move on, but ours were no where to be seen. With 10 minutes to go until boarding the connection flight was to begin, I informed a baggage handler who told us (Myself and my wife) and two other couples catching the same connection flight (who had also not got their bags) to head to the gate, board, and take it up with the airline on arrival in London and they would arrange to have the luggage shipped to us which we reluctantly agreed to do. We then stood in a queue for another 30 minutes to pass through security, a process which I do not understand the necessity for as for those on connection flights we were not leaving the airport. By this point our flight was now well into boarding. At various stages when moving through the queue, myself and some others in the same situation addressed their concerns with airport staff, looking for reassurances that the baggage had been automatically transferred. Put simply, no one had a clue. Cue running through the airport, catching the small train to different departure gates, and more running as our names were called over the Airport tannoy system. Finally we made it, to board an aircraft full of annoyed looking fellow passengers who had been sat on board for some time. What I want to know is, why were we told on multiple occasions (and I'm talking 10-15 times) that regardless of our destination we were to collect our luggage, when in fact the whole time the airport had transferred it automatically? If this was a late decision, why did someone not make the effort to tell us? Why did no one at the airport have the slightest idea? The process of filtering people through to their connections is flawed and over complicated. I was quite honestly sooner fly the opposite way around the world to my destination, that connect through Atlanta again.

author: Matt Moore
reviewBody: I am an international traveler and have visited hundreds of airports. I live in Atlanta and I need to provide some feedback. The people working at the airport from TSA to the airlines to the food service workers need an attitude adjustment. The most unfriendly, uninterested, rude, and unhappy employees I have seen anywhere. This is not a welcoming place for visitors or residents. They mumble, make no eye contact or in the case of TSA bark at you like drill sergeants. You appear to be an interruption to their social activities or phones when seeking service. Hard to believe that Newark is more pleasant than Atlanta. How exactly does TSA scheduling happen? The flight and passenger volume is known well in advance but there are never enough lanes open, or they are disorganized like it's the first time they have ever screened passengers.

reviewBody: Saturday 7th May, complete shambles. 2 hours to get through passport control. author: Joy Browne
reviewBody: Atlanta has to be the worse airport in the world for transit. We landed there from Mexico with 1 hour 45 minutes to connect to our Virgin flight to London. Although we had an ESTA we were put in an immigration queue with about 50 other people and just 3 open desks. After standing there for 20 minutes and going nowhere I told the staff organising the queue that we had an ESTA and time was ticking for our connection. She just shrugged and said if you miss the flight you will just have to take the next one. Not acceptable, so I found another staff member and asked to go to the front of the queue, she said not without asking everyone individually if that was ok - seriously? I just stood at the top and shouted at everyone - got no objections so tagged on to another queue at the desk. After another 15 minutes he processed us as visitors to the USA taking a photo and finger prints. We then had to run round, find our bags, get through customs, put the bags another carousel and then join another great big queue to go through security. We had walked less than a 100 yards from start to finish so why we had to go through security again is beyond me. We then had to run downstairs for the transit train from Terminal E to Terminal F where a guy from Virgin was waiting at the top of the escalator for us and radioed the gate that we were on the way as 5 more minutes and we would have been offloaded. Talk about a stressful and totally unnecessary performance just to transit through an airport. Really not good enough for this day and age - bad organisation, rude and useless staff. I've never had to deal with such a badly organised flight connection.

author: Margaret Patrick
reviewBody: I would avoid Atlanta airport at all costs. I missed my connecting flights both ways because of the sheer incompetence and indifference of the staff. More than 300 non-US passengers had to be processed at immigration on the outward journey. This took 3 hours standing in a queue because staff just stood around chatting. After an hour they half-heartedly began filtering people depending on the documentation they held. Announcements were made so incoherently that they could not be heard. Some of the staff processing travellers through the finger and eye recognition channels were unbelievably rude and treated us like simpletons. On our return connection through Baton Rouge we were also delayed because of problems at Atlanta which resulted in missed connections and baggage that that could not be tracked. Atlanta is a very large airport but, on the basis of my experience, the infrastructure cannot sustain its capacity and customer numbers. I was extremely disappointed - as someone who had not flown since 1983 I was very apprehensive but had coped much better than expected with the flights (KLM and Delta). My experiences of Atlanta airport soured my overall memories. There is a very serious need for staff training in use of initiative and basic good manners.

reviewBody: ✅ Verified Review |  Arrived with Delta Air Lines on April 23 at around 1pm, in transit to Fort Lauderdale, departure at 3pm. We were over 100 persons in queue - only one (1) employee serving at the roundabout 20 parallel control points. The queue hardly advanced, frustrated people everywhere. After 1.5 hrs it was our turn. We hurried on, but were told to pick up our checked-in baggage and drop it at another location. We then entered another endless queue for security check. By the time we were thru, it was 3.30, our plane was gone. A nightmare. We do not mind the security rules, but we hate being disrespectfully treated.

reviewBody: Travelling from Punta Cana to Las Vegas via Atlanta on Delta. Good signage on arrival at the airport showing separate lanes for US citizens and all others. Immigration hall for non-US with lots of booths but only 2 manned. One family dared to step over the yellow line and this was the trigger for the immigration officer from the other booth (50% of the workforce) to leap out of his booth and start shouting 'this is not gonna work, this is not gonna work' pointing at the yellow line. A simple,'excuse me could you please step back a little' would have sufficed. The other immigration official seemed mildly amused (or embarrassed). We were lucky that our connecting flight was in the same E concourse or it may have been a rush with a 90 min connection.

author: Jan Cafferty
reviewBody: Transit at this airport was a nightmare. Upon arrival the immigration staff were sat at their kiosks but not working, this must have been the case for an amount of time because a number of passengers in the queue before us had sat down on the floor. When the staff eventually started working it took ages to be processed because of the small number of staff and the long queue that had built up. I answered yes to the question had I been on a pasture recently, this instigated a secondary inspection which involved our cases being x-rayed for a second time just to be asked if I had the footwear with me that I'd worn on the pasture, which I hadn't. Then it was time to pass through security prior to our next flight, Friday afternoon when a lot of people are commuting home for the weekend and they only had two body scanners in use. Add to that how rude the staff are and all in all it wasn't a pleasant experience.

author: Rich Jenkins
reviewBody: This was my hometown airport for many years and has remained a periodic part of my itineraries and, on balance, one of my least favorite airports. I've always cleared immigration/customs elsewhere, so I cant comment on that experience. Somethings have improved, others have gotten worse and many remain just awful as ever. The airport food choices have improved and its become a little easier to eat something "healthy" other than prepackaged salads. There are ample charging stations and there is now free wifi, although it is time limited. Shopping is now more upscale which some may find a plus - basically, its the kind of place one finds in other airports like Brook Brothers. Seating in the Delta gates has been revised to provide more individual seating, but it makes gates more awkward and provides less seating, overall. Security lines seem worse - back to where they were 10 years ago. TSA Precheck is available but one needs to ask about it and even then it's poorly signed and requires multiple questions to fins (it's off to the side in the South Concourse). The concourses are long and have no motorized walkways. Those who can walk have to dodge the motorized carts for those who can't walk. Delta still has no idea how to board a plane - they have more agents at the gate but no sense of team work. The merger with Northwest resulted in flight attendants doing their jobs rather than hiding in the galleys, but there's been no similar transformation at the gate, esp. here. And CNN remains inescapable, loud and dumber than ever. ATL remains an annoying airport to traverse with weak customer service and has become only slightly better as a place to kill time during the inevitable delays.
